Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Predicting Domain-level Reading Comprehension Difficulty to Support Adult Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Regardless of their level of education, participants in the modern workforce are expected to be flexible in their ability to read and learn in new, often technical domains, including scientific subfields, medicine, policy, and care. Remarkably, however, there is little, if any, technological support for such learning, which often is dynamic and requires reading texts as needed rather than in an ordered curriculum as in classroom learning. This Early Grant for Exploratory Research addresses the need for technological support for adult learning in technical domains by exploring the feasibility of simulating the behavior of an expert reader in identifying important content and drawing inferences to connect rich background knowledge and the text at hand. Readers will be provided access to pilot implementations of the inferences and importance judgements of the simulated expert, to focus their attention and strengthen their comprehension of the text.

This development of exploratory models of expert reader behavior relies on techniques for characterizing text vocabulary into technical and plain language by contrasting word occurrence statistics in the domain and in general text such as in a random sample of telephone conversations or news. It will also explore the adaptation of techniques for definition mining and for deriving prototypical event sequences and shallow ontologies from large volume of typical domain text.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning develops over time. Prior knowledge, learned prior to reading a given text, is often necessary to understand a text. In human learning, it is important to ascertain that concepts assumed to be familiar to the person have indeed been mastered in prior learning. For intelligent systems, it is important to know what prior knowledge they bring to the analysis of a text.

 

 

As part of this grant, we were able to quantify the implicit knowledge about people available in modern systems for language analysis. We demonstrated that language representations encode common stereotypes about people, such as "Ex-husbands are neurotic" and "Canadians are agreeable". Our results have important implications for further developments in language understanding, because it showcases that the numerous studies to remove gender stereotypes for example are not likely to be fully successful given the extent to which we see stereotypical knowledge encoded in word representations. 
In analysis of news text, we also find that automated text understanding systems for English have a very American-centric ability to recognize people mentioned in text. This raises the concern that such technologies will not work well for texts focused on people from other parts of the world, leading to potential bias. Our work has led us to a roadmap for future system development that can lead to more robust and fiar systems.
Finally, we attempted to quantify the resources available to K-12 students to develop familiarity with scientific vocabulary and concepts. Such familiarity will possibly improve science education in the K-12 classroom and later in college. We have developed a preliminary list of books for children listed under science classification in the library of congress catalogue and that have received good ratings from readers on Amazon Books and GoodReads. In future work we will expand this foundation into a reading list appropriate for specific K-12 grades organized topically. The hope is that these resources will be beneficial to parents, school librarians and teachers.
